script: MAN: West Virginia Collegiate Institute is the best school for Negros in the state.
It's the only school past the eighth grade anywhere near here.
MAN: They're offering a full scholarship.
All you have to do is get there.
Ms. Coleman, why don't you solve the equation on the board?
WOMAN: We took up a collection amongst the teachers and such.
It's not a lot, but it's enough to help get you settled in.
That's more than kind, Ms. Sumner.
If the product of two terms is zero, then common sense says at least one of the two terms has to be zero to start with.
So if you move all the terms over to one side, you can put the quadratics into a form that can be factored, allowing that side of the equation to equal zero.
Once you've done that, it's pretty straightforward from there.
SUMNER: In all my years of teaching, I've never seen a mind like the one your daughter has.
SUMNER: You have to see what she becomes.
-WOMAN: Okay, try to turn it over now.
The starter is starting to make us late.
We all gonna end up unemployed riding around in this pile of junk to work every day.
You're welcome to walk the 16 miles.
-Or sit in the back of the bus.
No crime in a broken-down car.
Nobody wants to go to jail behind your mouth.
Not a great place for three of y'all be having car trouble.
We didn't pick the place, Officer. It picked us.
We're just on our way to work at Langley.
We do a great deal of the calculating.
I had no idea they hired...
There are quite a few women working in the space program.
Damn Russians are watching us right now.
You girls ever meet those astronauts?
Uh, yes, sir. We work with those gentlemen all the time.
Those boys are the best we got.
We gotta get a man up there before the commies do.
Whole damn country's counting on them.
Hard being of service broken down on the side of the road, though.
Well, do y'all need a tow or something?
Just need to bypass the starter.
Well, hell, least I can do is give y'all an escort.
I imagine you're running late to work.
No, sir. We wouldn't wanna bother you.
Hurry up, Dorothy, before he changes his mind.
He didn't mean up his behind!
Dear Lord, I don't even know where to begin!
Oh, I'll tell you where to begin.
Three Negro women are chasing a white police officer down the highway in Hampton, Virginia, 1961.
Ladies, that there is a God-ordained miracle.
And, tomorrow, I'm riding the bus.
Uh, it looks like they've achieved at least one orbit, maybe two.
Chernushka is ready to go again.
So is our comrade, Ivan, a brave space traveler.
We have proven life can be sustained in space.
Now we will be first to send a human...
WEBB: A damn dog and a damn mannequin.
And then a one-point-six megaton RDS-37 thermonuclear warhead drops down in the middle of Des Moines.
-Well, that's a pretty big jump, sir.
Paul Stafford, our lead engineer, Mr. Webb.
I think what he meant to say is that speculation, at least on our side of the equation, by definition can be just a little dangerous.
You know what's dangerous, Mr. Stafford?
The Russians have a spy satellite lapping the planet, taking pictures of God knows what!
The president is demanding an immediate response.
Alan Shepard, John Glenn, your Uncle Bob, it doesn't matter.
We can't justify a space program that doesn't put anything in space.
How'd that feel in there, Paul?
You think you enlightened the administrator?
No, he didn't look enlightened to me.
He look enlightened to you, Sam?
-And just so you know, he's not wrong about what he said in there.
Because now that they can get up there, a bomb will follow.
It's what happens to all our good ideas.
We don't have a single person in this entire building that can handle analytic geometry?
-Yeah. Well, tell me something else, Ruth, like we're gonna find such a person before the Russians plant a flag on the damn Moon.
DOROTHY: All right, Gloria, you'll be with engineering, building four.
If you're tardy, you don't get an assignment.
If you don't get an assignment, you don't have a job.
-Well, you're welcome to join the charmers -in Magnetoplasmadynamics.
The Mercury Seven prototype has arrived for testing.
Mr. Zielinski's requesting you for permanent assignment.
You will also be supporting the East group.
We're on double-time this morning, girls.
I need these calculations before lunch.
Space Task Group needs a computer, ASAP.
Someone with a handle on analytic geometry.
We can't fill that position out of the East group.
She can handle any numbers you put in front of her.
Didn't think I'd come all the way down here.
Was just wondering if they're still considering me for that position.
Yes. Well, the official word is no.
They're not assigning a permanent supervisor for the colored group.
We haven't had one since Miss Jansen got sick.
Things are working just fine as is.
I'm doing the work of a supervisor.
Fast with rocket ships, slow with advancement.
Get those trajectory calcs worked out.
We need them for the Redstone test.
No shoe is worth your life.
T-minus 10, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four...
If we alter the exterior from smooth to corrugated, the capsule might have more stability.
But the friction it is under during reentry...
Most shield erosion occurs on the posterior side abutting the retro-boosters.
The area closest to the boosters is closest to the heat.
Coupled with rise in temperature on reentry, the contact softens.
We could consider another fastener other than the bolts.
There is another opening in the engineer training program.
Flat head rivets would reduce wind drag.
Mary, a person with engineer's mind should be an engineer.
You can't be a computer the rest of your life.
Mr. Zielinski, I'm a Negro woman.
I'm not gonna entertain the impossible.
And I'm a Polish Jew whose parents died in a Nazi prison camp.
Now I'm standing beneath a spaceship that's going to carry an astronaut to the stars.
I think we can say we are living the impossible.
Let me ask you, if you were a white male, would you wish to be an engineer?
MITCHELL: Skirts must be worn past the knee.
Your supervisor is Mr. Al Harrison, director of the Space Task Group.
You'll write research, proof calculations, so forth.
Do not talk to Mr. Harrison unless he talks to you.
Not many computers last more than a few days.
He's been through a dozen in as many months.
They've never had a colored in here before, Katherine.
Take the desk in the back.
Mr. Harrison won't warm up to you. Don't expect it.
Do your work, keep your head down.
Why are we still losing shingles off the heat shield?
We're working with a prototype of the capsule, Al.
-Its lid is one-third the size-- -I get that. So...
what do we do with our million-dollar fan, Karl?
-No, Al. I don't think-- It was a joke.
Paul, if the heat shield comes off, what do you think happens to our astronaut?
We're gonna come up with a solve, right?
HARRISON: Ruth, what's the status on that computer?
She's right behind you, Mr. Harrison.
You think you can find me the Frenet frame for this data?
I prefer it over Euclidean coordinates.
Good, then I'm gonna need it by the end of the day.
I'm also gonna ask you to check Mr. Stafford's math as well as others' on this floor from time to time.
But if that were the case, shingles wouldn't be flying off the heat shield, now would they?
Excuse me, could I have everyone's attention for a moment?
Just to be clear, in 14 days, the Mercury Seven will be here for training.
And I have no doubt in my mind that they're going to be asking us questions about our work.
I think that's pretty reasonable given we're putting a human on top of a missile, shooting him into space, -and it's never been done before.
Because it's never been done, everything we do between now and then is gonna matter.
It's gonna matter to their wives, to their children.
I believe it's gonna matter to the whole damn country.
So this Space Task Group will be as advertised.
America's greatest engineering and scientific minds are not gonna have a problem with having their work checked.
Good. So let's have an amen, damn it.
-I'm not gonna be able-- -Work on what you can read.
RUTH: These are the numbers Mr. Harrison gave me.
May I ask where the ladies' room is?
Sorry. I have no idea where your bathroom is.
Ruth, where's that girl with the numbers?
My God, where have you been?
Almost. He said by the end of the day.
The end of the day around here is yesterday.
Somebody's working on it right now.
Oh, yeah. Uh, just set it-- you know.
It's hard to be sure, sir.
You know what we're doing here?
Trying to put a man into space, sir.
I said you can throw it away.
It's not an insult to your work.
That's how fast things are moving around here.
If I said I was sorry, I'd be saying it all day.

What I'm asking you to do, what I'm asking everyone in that room, all my geniuses, is to look beyond the numbers, to look around them, through them, for answers to questions we don't even know to ask.
Because without it, we're not going anywhere.
I mean, we're staying on the ground.
We're not flying into space, we're not circling the Earth, and we're certainly not touching the Moon.
In my mind, I'm already there.
Because I don't need another smart girl with an adding machine.
I haven't been late one day in 10 years.
It's not fair, that's a fact.
What's not fair is having the responsibility of a supervisor -but not the title or the pay.
And watching you two move on.
Any upward movement is movement for us all.
Truth be told, Dorothy, I don't even know if I can keep up in that room.
I'll be back with the computers in a week.
You're better with the numbers than anyone in there, Katherine, and you know it.
Just make that pencil move as fast as your mind does, you'll be fine.
Get your damn feet off my dashboard.
I sound like a supervisor, don't I?
You don't mess with Mrs. Vaughan.
I was fixing to call the National Guard.
But you want the job, right?
Well, it's nothing you can't handle, Katherine.
It's not fair how Joylette gets to sleep by herself because she's the oldest.
Now, I understand you want to be grown and have your own space.
So, whoever sleeps in that bed, in Joylette's place, will also do the dishes, take out the trash, and do all of Joylette's chores.
Yeah, she's not so terrible to share with.
Okay. Then don't let me come home and find you like this again, you hear me?
You're supposed to been asleep a long time ago.
We just wanted to say good night.
I know. I work a full-time job now.
I have to be Mommy and Daddy.
I miss your father just as much as anyone.
Yes, he's with all the angels.
That's why we have to be strong.
Are the Russians fixin' to attack us?
We had to hide under our desks today, all scrunched up.
Okay, baby, that's called a drill.
you practice safety just in case something happens.
Truth is, we don't know what they're doing up there.
But I'm going to do what I can to help those brave men get there. Yes, I am.
You could fly up to space if you wanted to, Mama.
All right. Now this time really go to bed.
From the Southern Christian Leadership Conference to the good Reverend Dr. King...
...to the students sitting in at lunch counters in North Carolina.
His faith in us has no limit.
The good Lord has our very own women working on rocket ships.
And we have National Guardsmen defending our freedom.
Give a shout of praise for Colonel Jim Johnson.
Returning home, by the grace of God to set up a National Guard unit right here in Hampton.
-Can I get a hallelujah in here?
I don't wanna talk about this again, okay?
It's not like that there, Levi.
Freedom is never granted to the oppressed.
It's got to be demanded, taken.
Stop quoting your slogans at me.
There is more than one way to achieve something.
You're gonna eat them greens, too.
Kids need to eat their vegetables.
You'd know that if you was ever home.
You better settle down, Levi Jackson.
Unless you want this female's mind, right here, in front of everybody.
All I'm saying, don't play the fool.
I don't wanna see you get hurt.
NASA's never, ever given you gals your due.
Having a couple of extra degrees ain't gonna change that.
I don't want any greens either.
Your brother gets them, and so do you.
I hear he's planning on staying in the area.
Katherine, go find your way over there.
That Colonel Jim is a tall glass of water.
And I bet he's like that day and night.
-Hmm, I think he's smiling over here.
Come over here and say hi.
She's a widow, with three beautiful little girls.
Angels on Earth is what we like to call them.
-You already have a slice of pie, Dorth-- -Uh-huh.
Well, I was just, uh, fixing my three babies some plates.
Pastor mentioned you're a computer at NASA.
Um... we calculate the mathematics necessary to enable launch and landing for the space program.
I'm just surprised that something so...
If I were you, I'd quit talking right now.
I will have you know, I was the first Negro female student at West Virginia University Graduate School.
On any given day, I analyze the manometer levels for air displacement, friction, and velocity, and compute over 10,000 calculations by cosine, square root, and, lately, analytic geometry.
There are 20 bright, highly capable Negro women in the West Computing Group, and we're proud to be doing our part for the country.
And it's not because we wear skirts.
HARRISON: Good to have you here, gentlemen.
That's Alan Shepard, US Navy pilot.
He could be the first man in space.
And that's Scott Carpenter and Walter Schirra, also Navy pilots.
And handsome must be a requirement too.
How could you possibly be ogling these white men?
I have the right to see fine in every color.
He's the only Marine Corps pilot.
Gentlemen, if we may, much to see around here.
Well, heck, we haven't shaken all the hands yet.
We have a fairly tight itinerary, Colonel.
Ladies, I didn't wanna run off without saying hello.
They seem to be in a big rush around here.
Well, the Russians certainly aren't slowing down any.
You know, they can't build a damn refrigerator.
-How the heck did they beat us into space?
GLENN: And what do you ladies do for NASA?
-You can't get anywhere without the numbers.
And I'm proud as the devil to be working with you.
Mr. Harrison wants you to confirm launch and landing for the Redstone rocket test.
I cannot work on what I cannot see, Mr. Stafford.
Those numbers have already been confirmed by two engineers in this department and myself.
This is more or less a dummy check.
We have one, you make it two.
You gotta get it-- Just make it happen.
No one thought to measure these things?
Well, would you like us to stop?
In fact, use the big hammer.
Come on, use the big hammer.
Our runner can pick up your work, Dorothy.
You need to be working, not walking.
Well, since you made the trip, you can take that batch over there.
I was wondering if you know what they're building over in the tech wing.
Apparently, it can do our calculations in a fraction of the time.
I guess that's good for NASA.
What are you looking at, Paul?
I said, whose work is that?
PAUL: How did you know the Redstone couldn't support orbital flight?
Well, it's no secret why the Redstone tests keep failing.
It's fine for suborbital flight, but it can't handle the weight of the capsule and push it into space.
And you figured all that out with this?
Well, what's there tells a story if you read between the lines.
The distance from launch to orbit, we know.
And the speeds are there in the data.
And how do you know about the Atlas rocket?
I held it up to the light.
-You held it up to the light?
-I said, are you a Russian spy?
All right then, we have nothing to lose here.
Give her everything she needs to work on Shepard's trajectories without redaction.
I-- I just don't think it's a good idea.
You know what I think's a good idea? Darker ink.
I think darker ink's a good idea.
MARY: You can probably get to the Moon and back with this.
Well, at least they're not blind of what you do.
This IBM's gonna put us all out of work.
Learn all we can, make ourselves valuable.
Somewhere down the line, a human being is gonna have to push the buttons.
NASA doesn't commission females for the engineer training program.
That position is available to any qualified applicant.
Right. Except, you don't have the educational requirements.
I have a bachelor's degree in mathematics and physical science.
It's the same as most engineers around here.
Well, we now require advanced extension courses through the University of Virginia.
It's in the employee handbook, in addendum.
In case you haven't read it.
Every time we have a chance to get ahead, they move the finish line.
I just follow the rules around here, and I expect everyone who works for me to follow them as well.
There are no special circumstances for anyone.
Y'all should be thankful you have jobs at all.
For those that cannot attend classes at the University of Virginia, advanced extension courses are available at the Hampton High School.
That's still a segregated school, Mary.
Virginia acts like Brown versus Board of Education never happened.
They are never gonna allow a colored woman to just take classes at an all-white school.
Well, I'm not gonna sit here all day and listen to you complain about the way things are.
I'm as fine as I have ever been.
You're drunk as you've ever been.
Go and dance with her, Katherine.
-We gonna teach you how to dance.
We gonna teach you how to get a man.
You got to know how to dance.
Can I win me one of those fancy dance contests?
Don't pay attention to all that.
We're not part of that trouble. Go on.
We don't want any trouble in here.
Oh, I'm not here for any trouble, ma'am.
You have books in the colored section.
It doesn't have what I'm looking for.
Well, that's just the way it is.
Get your hands off my boys!
DOROTHY: Separate and equal are two different things.
Just 'cause it's the way, doesn't make it right.
You act right, you are right.
And taxes pay for everything in that library.
You can't take something you already paid for.
Fortran is a new and exciting language used by programmers to communicate with computers.
It is exciting as it is the wave of the future.
Leonard, you need to get you a job now.
Let me go help him with those flowers.
I believe I owe you an apology.
Can I make it while we dance?
I'm afraid I simply misspoke the other day, Mrs. Goble.
I've been away for a long time.
I imagine I'm just out of practice.
I was hoping you'd allow me to start over.
See, the thing is, I have an interest in getting to know you better.
You haven't said you're sorry yet.
Though I don't imagine there's many.
We interrupt this musical programming with breaking news.
The Soviet news agency has announced that Russian cosmonaut, Yuri Gagarin, has become the first man in space.
Gagarin completed one full orbit around the planet in 108 minutes.
Stay tuned to this station for more details as they become available.
Well, guess that puts us behind the curve.

ANNOUNCER: The Vostok-1 rocket delivered Russian cosmonaut Yuri Gagarin's 3KA capsule into orbit at 6:07 UTC, reentering Russian airspace at 7:55 UTC, proving conclusively that man could survive orbital space flight.
Gagarin was awarded the Order of Lenin and the Gold Star-- Well, they beat the pants off us. Let's go.
Let's learn how to fly to space.
ANNOUNCER: First Soviet Astronaut, and has been proclaimed a national hero.
This is a day of unprecedented triumph for the Russian space program and a crushing blow for America in the race for space.
I want to thank everyone for staying.
I know it's late, and after what I just saw, I'm sure everyone's probably anxious to just go home.
Before we do, I just have to ask a question...
the same one I've been asking myself all the way over here, which is...
How in the hell did we find ourself in second place in a two-man race?
And I think Glenn said it pretty well.
The reason I have to think that is because I refuse to believe that the Russians are smarter than us or that they have more technology or that they care more.
Is it possible that it actually means more to them?
We're in the fight of our lives, people.
We're not on some epic joyride.
I just saw seven faces who aren't sure that we can get there.
And so as of right now...
there's only two things you need to know going forward.
One is staying here, working late, that's gonna be a fact of life.
And two, don't expect your paychecks to reflect the extra time it's gonna take to catch up and pass those bastards.
For those of you who can't work that way, I understand and thank you for what you've done.
I suggest you call your wives and tell them how it's gonna be.
Sir, it might be the selector latch.
We're honored to serve our country.
So we don't think about danger.
We don't have time to be scared.
We got a job to do.
Colored seats are at the back of the courtroom.
So, which one of you wants to go first?
It has the capability of solving over 24,000 multiplications...
They'll never get that to work.
And when it does, we have to know how to program it.
Unless you'd rather be out of a job.
The computer uses it as its high-speed storage unit, an information-holding device.
Well, that's in the wrong spot.
Get me the Cape on the line.
Shepard's trajectories need to be updated.
when we slumber Where the hell have you been?
Everywhere I look, you're not where I need you to be.
Now where the hell do you go every day?
What do you do in there?
There's no bathroom for me here.
What do you mean there's no bathroom for you here?
There are no colored bathrooms in this building or any building outside the West Campus, which is half a mile away.
I have to walk to Timbuktu just to relieve myself.
And I can't use one of the handy bikes.
My uniform-- skirt below my knees, my heels, and a simple string of pearls.
Lord knows you don't pay coloreds enough to afford pearls!
And I work like a dog, day and night, living off of coffee from a pot none of you wanna touch!
if I have to go to the restroom a few times a day.
Go wherever you damn well please.
Here at NASA, we all pee the same color.
Heard you was fighting the flu.
Figured you could use some soup.
Dear Lord, thank you for this meal.
We ask that you bless this food so that it may bless our bodies.
REPORTER: It's a historic day, here at Cape Canaveral, and here's what we can expect.
Alan Shepard and Freedom 7 will be launched into space at an altitude of about 116 miles an hour.
-Dorothy, come on, you gonna miss it!
...will land about 35 miles off the coast of Florida where he'll be picked up by the men of the USS Lake Champlain who set out for this historic purpose.
Freedom 7, we're going to have to bleed off some of the pressure inside the liquid oxygen tank.
That should reduce the temperature inside the capsule. Over.
Fix your little problem and light this candle.
Running one more launch status check.
We're at T-minus 10, nine, eight, seven, six, five, four, three, two, one, zero.
SHEPARD: Liftoff, and the clock is started.
Liftoff at 34 minutes after the hour.
JOHN F. KENNEDY: For the eyes of the world now look into space, to the Moon and to the planets beyond.
- And we have vowed that we shall not see it governed by a hostile flag of conquest but by a banner of freedom and peace.
We set sail on this new sea because there is new knowledge to be gained and new rights to be won.
We choose to go to the Moon in this decade and do the other things, not because they are easy, but because they are hard.
Suppose we should all thank President Kennedy for the continued job security.
Another suborbital flight with a Redstone.
It's our last shot before we strap Glenn to the Atlas and pray we can bring him back down.
Yes, and I imagine he'd like us to have the math worked out beforehand.
Go have dinner with your kids and let's get back to work.
I think it's high time I kissed you, Katherine.
Figured you attracted to me, same as I to you.
Or you would have told me to get going a long time ago.
Haven't kissed a man in a long time.
The FBI has arrested four white men accused of throwing a firebomb into a Freedom Rider bus outside of Anniston, Alabama.
All of us realized that the bus was on fire and had to go out into the mob.
-The kids don't need to be watching this.
Well, when we got off the bus in Birmingham...
LEVI: Everybody needs to see this.
...took me and forced me out of the door...
and threw me into the crowd.
And then I was beaten by one big guy and several others.
We think we're rendering a great service to our nation.
For this is not a struggle for ourselves alone.
It is a struggle to save the soul of America.
Petition to attend courses at Hampton High School Good morning, Your Honor.
Hampton High School is a white school, Mrs. Jackson.
Regardless of what the federal government says, regardless of what the Supreme Court says, our law is the law.
I believe there are special circumstances to be considered.
What would warrant a colored woman attending a white school?
May I approach your bench, sir?
Your Honor, you of all people should understand the importance of being first.
Well, you were the first in your family to serve in the armed forces.
And the first state judge to be recommissioned by three consecutive governors.
The point is, Your Honor, no Negro woman in the state of Virginia has ever attended an all-white high school.
And before Alan Shepard sat on top of a rocket, no other American had ever touched space.
And now, he will forever be remembered as the US Navy man from New Hampshire, the first to touch the stars.
And I, sir, I plan on being an engineer at NASA, but I can't do that without taking them classes at that all-white high school.
And I can't change the color of my skin.
So I have no choice but to be the first.
Which I can't do without you, sir.
Your Honor, out of all the cases you're gonna hear today, which one is gonna matter a hundred years from now?
Which one is gonna make you the first?
Only the night classes, Mrs. Jackson.
How late did he say he was gonna be?
I'd like to get a jump on John Glenn's trajectory.
Do you have any idea what you're asking?
An orbital launch with an Atlas rocket is going to take time.
Uh-huh. Well, I've been wondering my whole life, so you just spit it out.
I would like to get a jump on John Glenn's trajectory.
This isn't about plugging in numbers.
And I think you and I talked about that, right?
Do you have any idea how exacting these calculations have to be?
It's like shooting a sawed-off shotgun from a thousand feet and getting that one BB through a hole so tiny, you can't even see it.
-Okay, let me see what you've got.
How have the Grissom numbers been?
-But you run it all through Stafford, understood?
-Okay, it's a nice ride up to now.
Liberty Bell 7, this is Hunt 1 approaching.
GRISSOM: I read you loud and clear. Over.
TV REPORTER: The Liberty Bell 7 capsule is taking on water.
Gus Grissom is out of the capsule.
Rescuers are now going to pull him from the ocean waves.
Unfortunately, the Liberty Bell 7 capsule is lost.
Mr. Harrison, taxpayer money sank in the ocean along with your capsule.
So what makes you think you can bring John Glenn home safely?
Let me say first, discovery is never just for the sake of discovery, gentlemen, but for the sake of human survival, and it will always come with a risk.
Whoever gets there first will make the rules, that's been true of every civilization.
And so, I think the bigger question for this body to consider is who do you want calling the shots in space?
We have to know what's out there, Senator.
We have to touch the stars, if only to ensure our own survival, and only a man can do that.
We'll get John Glenn home safely because we have to, because he has to tell us what he saw.
PAUL: The Redstone rocket went straight up.
But the capsule didn't have enough speed to go into orbit, so it came back down.
Essentially a triangle: Earth, suborbit, Earth.
Now, the Atlas rocket, that can push us into orbit.
Goes up, delivers the capsule into an elliptical orbit.
Earth's gravity keeps pulling at it, but it's going so fast, it keeps missing the Earth.
That's how it stays in orbit.
Now, getting it back down, that's the math we don't know.
So the capsule will spin around the Earth forever because there's nothing to slow it down?
Slowing it down at precisely the right moment, at precisely the right amount, that's the task.
So it needs to move from an elliptical orbit...
Now at this point, it's a pinhead.
We bring him in too late, he's pushed out of Earth's gravity.
And any changes to mass, weight, speed, time, distance, friction, or a puff of wind would alter the go-no-go, and we start our calculations over.
So we need to be able to choose this reentry point.
Now this go-no-go, this has to be exact.
These are the latest Redstone numbers in current capsule data.
A Pentagon briefing should illuminate where the Navy needs the recovery zone, then we work backwards from there.
And the rest is on us, so let's get to work.
If I could attend the briefings, I'd be more useful to the project.
Yes, but if we don't have the information of the changes, we can't keep up.
I need those changes as they occur.
As you said, it's a pinhead.
You asked for this assignment, so just calculate with what you have.
Or we'll find someone who can.
Hey, what the hell are you doing?
I'm with the West Computing Group.
Well, this is a very delicate piece of equipment.
We're altering the window on the capsule.
Sir, if I could attend the briefings, I could stay current-- Katherine, we have been through this.
There is no protocol for women attending.
There's no protocol for a man circling the Earth either, sir.
Okay. That is just the way things are.
Colonel Glenn's launch coordinates, accounting for the window change, sir.
Computers don't author reports. Fix it.
